docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof's description of Prudence Lemokouno's last hours (''Prudence's Struggle Ends,'' column, Sept. 24) was heartbreaking, and the fact that these needless deaths are concentrated among poor, rural African women is blatantly unjust.
docs.abstract: Family Care International pres Jill W Sheffield letter holds that Nicholas D Kristof's description of Prudence Lemokouno's pregnancy-related death in Cameroon hospital was heartbreaking, and fact that these needless deaths are concentrated among poor, rural African women is blatantly unjust (Sept 24 Op-Ed)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Nicholas D. Kristof's description of Prudence Lemokouno's last hours (''Prudence's Struggle Ends,'' column, Sept. 24) was heartbreaking, and the fact that these needless deaths are concentrated among poor, rural African women is...

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge has struck down a state law restricting the use of an abortion-inducing pill, calling the law vague and saying it could jeopardize women’s health. The ruling, made Wednesday by Judge Susan J. Dlott of Federal District Court, came two years after a court challenge by Ohio abortion providers. The 2004 law, which had never taken effect, bars doctors from prescribing mifepristone, or RU-486, after the seventh week of pregnancy. Mark Anthony, a spokesman for Attorney General Jim Petro, said his office was reviewing the ruling and had not decided whether to appeal.

headline.main: Ohio: Judge Rejects Down Abortion Pill Restrictions
headline.print_headline: OHIO: JUDGE REJECTS ABORTION PILL RESTRICTIONS
